They attain giving, morality, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom, yet do not give rise to an attached mind or discriminate objects in all places;

Knowing that all dharmas are unborn and unceasing, yet always not abandoning the diligent protection of the Dharma;
Not seeing sentient beings or the name of sentient beings, yet always not abandoning the diligent transformation of all sentient beings to attain great enlightenment.

This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's entry into ten kinds of dharma practices, able to understand the meaning of dharma masters.

By accomplishing speech that is free from the latent tendencies of all afflictions, one is able to extinguish the causes of afflictions and secondary afflictions;

They rely on teachings that cut off the propensities of ordinary beings, not on teachings that cut off the propensities of Buddhas, Dharma, and Sangha.
They rely on teachings that benefit others with great kindness and compassion, not on teachings that seek one's own happiness.
Those who expound the Dharma rely on the profound Dharma, because it is ultimately empty, signless, and wishless.
Those who expound the Dharma rely on those superior people, because they are able to turn the great Dharma wheel.

The Dharma teacher speaks with the subjugation of all demons and enemies, because he is able to subdue the demon of the aggregates, the demon of death, the demon of afflictions, and the demon of the heavens;
The Dharma teacher speaks in accordance with the site of enlightenment, because he is to be revered by all worlds;

The Dharma teacher speaks in accordance with the wisdom of omniscience, because he will ultimately attain the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, and the eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha.
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's entry into ten kinds of dharma practices, by means of which he is able to understand the meaning of a Dharma teacher.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas enter ten kinds of dharma practices and are able to understand the meaning of a Dharma teacher.
What are the ten?
Namely, delighting in the conduct of pure conduct and the activities of livelihood, not delighting in worldly means of livelihood;
Delighting in the practices of the sages, yet not abandoning the reproachable activities of ordinary beings in order to teach and transform sentient beings;

They always enjoy accomplishing the ten powers, four fearlessnesses, and eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, and do not enjoy only realizing the four noble truths;
They always enjoy severing the afflictions and habitual tendencies of all sentient beings, and do not only enjoy severing the afflictions and obstacles;
They always enjoy severing all afflictions and the habitual tendencies of afflictions, and do not only enjoy severing the afflictions and obstacles.

This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's entry into ten kinds of dharma practices, by which one can understand the meaning of a dharma master.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who enter these ten kinds of practices can understand the appropriate parables of Dharma masters.
What are the ten?
It is said, good sons!
It is like the earth, whose nature is impartial and can widely support all beings, yet it does not seek gratitude from beings.
Good sons!
The Dharma masters of bodhisattvas are like that earth, their minds impartial and able to widely support all beings, yet they do not seek gratitude from beings.
Good sons!
It is like great water, whose nature is universally nourishing, moistening all and causing them to flourish, yet it does not seek gratitude from those things.
Bodhisattva Dharma masters are also like this, using their own merits to benefit beings and causing them all to be at ease, yet they do not seek gratitude from beings.
Good sons!
It is like the nature of fire, whose power can ripen all fruits, yet it has no expectations for those things.

The Dharma Master Bodhisattva is also like this. With his own merits and wisdom, he brings all sentient beings' wholesome roots and fruits to maturity, yet he does not seek gratitude from sentient beings.
Good man!
It is like the nature of wind, which has the power to grow all herbs and seeds, yet it does not give rise to discrimination towards those things and has no expectations.

The Dharma Master Bodhisattva is also like this. He has the power to increase the growth of all sentient beings' physical bodies and Dharma bodies, yet he does not seek repayment from sentient beings.
Good man!
It is like the realm of space, which is immeasurable, boundless, unobstructed, and contains everything, yet it does not discriminate or cling to those things.

The Dharma Master Bodhisattva is also like this. He accomplishes immeasurable and boundless wholesome merits, is unobstructed, and benefits all sentient beings, yet he does not discriminate or cling to sentient beings.
Good sons!

It is like the bright moon appearing in the sky, pure and perfect, all beings who see it love it, its light illuminates all things in the world, yet it is not polluted by the darkness and obscurations.

The Dharma masters, the bodhisattvas, are also like this. They appear in the world, endowed with merit, all who see them love them, they save and liberate the world without being tainted by worldly dharmas.
Good sons!

It is like the sun rising, its light illuminating everywhere, dispelling all darkness and obscurity, all the activities of beings are accomplished, yet the nature of the sun has no discrimination towards beings, no desire for gratitude in return.

The Dharma Master Bodhisattva is also like this. Appearing in the world, he destroys the darkness of ignorance of sentient beings, illuminating them with the light of wisdom, causing the various wholesome roots to flourish. Yet that Bodhisattva has no discrimination towards sentient beings and does not seek even the slightest reward.
Good man!
It is like a ship that is sturdy, thick, and well-bound, not broken or damaged, able to ferry sentient beings across the great ocean, yet not seeking payment from the sentient beings.

The Dharma Master Bodhisattva is also like this. Using wisdom as the thickness, the perfections as the sturdiness, and great compassion as the good binding, he is able to ferry sentient beings across the great ocean of birth and death, yet not seeking payment from the sentient beings.
Good man!
It is like a violent river, flowing swiftly and dangerously.
In the middle, there are bridges, equally providing the joy of crossing over to all beings, without the thought of crossing over with discrimination.

The bodhisattva Dharma master is also like this, able to make a great bridge in the difficult to cross, dangerous, fearful, swift flowing evil paths of the violent river of afflictions, equally bestowing the joy of liberation to all beings, without the mind of liberation with discrimination.
Good man!
It is like a great lamp burning in a dark room, equally illuminating all beings of the lower, middle, and upper levels, and that lamp light has no thought of illuminating with 'mine' or 'I'.

The bodhisattva Dharma master is also like this, burning the lamp of wisdom in the dark room of ignorance, equally illuminating all beings of the lower, middle, and upper levels, and that bodhisattva has no mind of illuminating with 'mine' or 'I'.
Good man!
These are called the ten kinds of dharmic practices that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas enter in order to know the concordance with the characteristics of dharma masters through parables.

What are the ten?
Namely, they do not cohabit with those of small mind, few desires, and narrow inferiority;
They also do not cohabit with those of indolent mind, those who do not give rise to vast mind, and those who do not give rise to great practices;
They also do not cohabit with those sentient beings who rely on the mind of arrogance, the arrogance of superiority, and the arrogance of self, which are like lofty banners;
They do not cohabit with those sentient beings who are stingy, jealous, violate precepts, harbor anger and resentment, are indolent, have distracted minds, and are foolish and ignorant;
They do not cohabit with those who have minds that are full of greed, anger, and the contemplation of harming others;
They also do not cohabit with all kinds of discrimination, differentiation, and various discriminations;
They also do not cohabit with all the hindrances, afflictions, and entanglements;

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's entry into ten kinds of dharma practices in order to know the supreme fruition of all roots of goodness.
What are the ten?
They are as follows, good man!
It is just like how, due to the moon in the sky, one sees various moon reflections in the water, yet the moon in the sky does not enter the water.
Good man!
In this way, due to the causes and conditions of the practice of wholesome roots, there are various excellent and wonderful fruits and rewards, all accomplished according to one's wishes.

Just as the moon in the sky does not enter the water, in the same way, the causes and conditions of the wholesome roots created do not reach the fruits. Although they do not reach the fruits, due to those causes and conditions of wholesome roots, there are superior and wonderful fruits and rewards with different distinctions.

in the same way, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, due to the causes and conditions of the practice of wholesome roots, have immeasurable distinctions in the fruits and rewards.

Good sons!

It is like relying on those supreme wholesome practices, naturally creating various musical performances, subtle sounds, and joyful events in the sky as offerings, yet those wholesome practices do not reach the sounds of music, because those wholesome practices and the various musical performances are different from each other.
Although their characteristics are different, based on those karmic actions, there are various musical performances in the sky.

In this way, based on the causes and conditions of the roots of goodness and karmic practices, there are superior fruits and retributions. However, those good practices do not reach the fruits. Although they do not reach the fruits, based on the causes and conditions of those roots of goodness, there are superior fruits and retributions with different distinctions.
Good son!
It is like the sky with variegated rainbows arising, based on the dominant causes and conditions of the four great elements. However, those four great elements do not reach the rainbow.

Although they do not reach the rainbow, by the power of the causes and conditions of those four great elements, various different rainbow colors are produced - the earth element produces yellow color, the water element produces blue color, the fire element produces red and variegated colors, and the wind element produces the circular appearance of the rainbow.
In this way, based on the dominant causes and conditions of the roots of goodness, there are superior and wonderful fruits and rewards in abundance.
Good son!

In this way, because of the power of the wholesome roots of well-arisen supreme thoughts, well-performed practices, and good upholding, there is the supreme and wonderful fruit of the wheel-turning king. It is like the power of the causes and conditions of supreme spiritual powers, which are unobstructed by stone walls, yet those causes and conditions do not reach the unobstructed state, but rely on the existence of unobstruction based on those spiritual powers.
In this way, the causes and conditions of the roots of goodness of non-negligence have that supreme and wonderful fruition.
Good man!
It is like wind giving rise to fire, which does not arise apart from it.

In this way, the fruition of all the roots of goodness arises from causes and conditions.
